awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Improving Anion Exchange Membrane Water Electrolyzers via Novel Electrode Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to enable very highly-efficient low-cost green hydrogen production by improving a key functional component of a promising water electrolysis technology. Green hydrogen is a chemical fuel and a feedstock with no associated CO2 emissions. In an effort to decarbonize our economy, green hydrogen can address sectors of our economy that are not easily electrified using clean electricity, for example steelmaking, chemicals, heating, and heavy transport such as shipping and aviation. However, the cost of green hydrogen is still too high to prompt large-scale adoption. The pure-water electrolyzers developed in this project can significantly reduce green hydrogen production costs compared to the current state-of-the-art: they require only water and electricity as inputs, and are entirely made of low-cost, non-toxic materials, utilizing domestic supply chains. They are modular, enabling the development of both large hydrogen production facilities and small decentralized systems, e.g., for on-site operations or refueling stations. This project will not only help the adoption of green hydrogen, it will also elucidate how the chemical and electrochemical modifications of active surfaces can more broadly be used to make electrochemical reactions, such as water splitting, more efficient.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to drastically improve a key component of an anion exchange membrane water electrolyzer (AEMEL): the anode electrode. The anode is the site of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), a required but inefficient step during electrolytic hydrogen production. Enhancement of the OER kinetics by improved anode design, if translated to commercial AEMEL systems, would directly lead to a lower cost of green hydrogen. This project aims to replace the conventional two-layer anode, in which a complex catalyst layer is coated on top of a porous transport layer (PTL), with a simpler “unified” anode, in which the PTL is functionalized such that the catalyst layer is no longer necessary and the reaction kinetics are improved. In this project, two approaches to functionalize the PTL surface will be combined: the increase of the electrochemically active surface area (via etching, dealloying, and deposition techniques) and the increase of the intrinsic catalytic OER activity (via alloying and deposition techniques). This effort is expected to result in significantly improved AEMEL performance and lifetime, which will be evaluated using electrochemical methods, both ex situ (3-electrode cell) and in situ (in an operating electrolyzer).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Green hydrogen is essential for realizing net zero carbon emissions. Green hydrogen is produced by water electrolysis, a process in which renewable electricity is used to split water into oxygen and hydrogen. Currently, green hydrogen projects are held back by the high capital cost of water electrolyzer stacks. EvolOH aims to reduce this cost without sacrificing efficiency by leveraging cutting-edge technology. As we strive to make water electrolyzers better and cheaper, we are looking to simplify and optimize all key electrolyzer components while replacing expensive and hard-to-source materials with earth-abundant counterparts that enable low-risk domestic supply chains.

The anode is the most complex component of the water electrolyzer. It is typically responsible for the largest fraction of electrolysis inefficiencies and plays an important role in electrolyzer degradation. It also often contains extremely rare metals such as iridium and platinum. In this SBIR Phase I project, EvolOH has greatly simplified and optimized the anode electrode of the water electrolyzer. The developed unified anode combines several electrolyzer components into one and is highly active, durable, inexpensive, and simple to manufacture. We met or surpassed all proposed project milestones, building a strong foundation for further development and future commercialization. 

In this project, EvolOH developed and tested three categories of unified anodes, all aiming to modify the surface of a commercial porous substrate: first, we created a microporous electrode surface, thereby increasing the effective surface area and total catalytic activity; second, we changed the surface chemistry of the electrode, thereby increasing the intrinsic catalytic activity of the surface; third, we combined the first two categories, thereby making an electrode with both increased surface area and increased catalytic activity specific to that surface area. In each category, we synthesized a range of unified anodes, either ideated by our team or adapted from literature. We screened the effective activity of each unified anode, ex-situ, and integrated the best-performing anodes into our R&D-scale electrolyzer stacks. Both ex-situ and in-situ, the performance of the best unified anode far exceeded the performance of the untreated substrates and of our conventional anode. The durability of such performance improvements was also demonstrated. These results were demonstrated first in process conditions relevant to our fundamental research, and later in process conditions relevant to our commercial electrolyzers. 

This Phase I SBIR project was instrumental in our efforts to maximize the performance, efficiency, and durability of the anode electrode, while at the same time reducing production cost and improving supply chain security. It has implications for all anion exchange membrane (AEM) electrolyzers as well as for advanced alkaline electrolyzers. Our novel anode enables better water electrolyzers and contributes to a lower levelized cost of hydrogen. With such efforts, we aim to enable green hydrogen at a cost of $1 per kilogram. Further, our novel anode does not rely on any hard-to-source materials, enabling domestic supply chains and maximizing the potential for domestic job generation. Finally, our research and development at the intersection of energy technology, chemistry, electrochemistry, and nanotechnology may result in broader impacts in those fields by showcasing the value of interdisciplinary approaches. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2023
Modified by: Philipp K Muscher
